definition[0]: the process of moving or the way that someone or something moves
example[2]: The rocking motion of the boat made Sylvia feel sick.
definition[1]: a single movement of your head or hand, especially one made in order to communicate something
example[3]: Doyle glanced back at Bodie, and made a slight motion with his head.
example[4]: He summoned the waiter with a motion of his hand.
definition[2]: a proposal that is made formally at a meeting, and then is usually decided on by voting
example[5]: The motion was defeated by 201 votes to 159.
example[6]: I urge you to support this motion.
example[7]: The motion was seconded (=formally supported) by Mr Levin.
example[8]: The attorneys filed a motion (=made a proposal in a court) for a temporary restraining order.
example[10]: I’d like to propose a motion to move the weekly meetings to Thursdays.
example[11]: We will now vote on the motion that membership charges should rise by 15%.
definition[3]: solid waste material that comes out when you empty your bowels – used especially by doctors and nurses
definition[4]: to give someone directions or instructions by moving your hand or head
example[12]: The police officer motioned for me to pull over.
example[13]: He motioned to the barman to refill their glasses.
note[5]: motion to somebody to do something
example[15]: I saw her motioning me into the room.
definition[5]: a suggestion that is made formally at a meeting and then decided on by voting
example[16]: The motion was carried (=accepted) by 15 votes to 10.
